_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Hillsborough County Water Department (HCWD) has an accidental release prevention policy integrating technology, established procedures and management practices into a unified approach to risk management.  The HCWD operates a number of water and wastewater treatment facilities throughout unincorporated Hillsborough County, Florida.  Department facilities comply with applicable procedures and policies of the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the Florida Department of Environmental Protection and the Florida Department of Community Affairs.  The emergency response policy is specific to each plant and/or facility. Each facility is in compliance with the emergency response program requirements.

Northwest Regional Water Reclamation Facility

The Northwest Regional Water Reclamation Facility is located on a 67 acre parcel of land located northwest of Race Track Road and south of Mobley Road at 10890 South Mobley Road.  The site is part of a 1,500-acre mutli-use tract owned by the County.  The facility was built to process five (5) million gallons per day (MGD) of wastewater.  The plant currently treats three (3) million gallons per day.

Offsite Consequence Analysis

The offsite consequence analysis includes consideration of two chlorine release scenarios identified as "worst case scenario" and "alternative release".  The first scenario is defined by the EPA, which states that "the owner or operator shall assume that the ... maximum quantity in the largest vessel ... is released as a gas over 10 minutes,"  due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is identified as "more likely to occur than the worst case scenario."

The worst case scenario at the Northwest Regional Water Reclamation Facility involves an unspecified failure of a single one-ton container of chlorine.  The EPA-mandated conditions for worst case scenario assume the release of the entire contents as a gas in 10 minutes, use of the one hour ERPG-2 as the toxic endpoint, and con

sideration of the population residing within a full circle with radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance.  EPA set these conditions to facilitate the performance of the offsite consequence analysis.  The HCWD believes the  EPA assumptions to be unrealistic because:

     A.     Only a fraction of the compressed liquified chlorine released to the atmosphere flashes to a vapor. The remaining liquid forms liquid droplet aerosols. This results in the formation of a very dense chlorine cloud consisting of vapor and liquid droplets, with dispersion characteristics  significantly different than for a cloud of only chlorine gas.

     B.     Only the population within an elliptical plume extending downwind of the release point is potentially affected.  The plume area, or footprint, is approximately 6 percent of the area of the full circle. 

EPA-mandated meteriological conditions,  Stability F, wind speed of 1.5 m/second, highest daily maximum temperature and average humidity are used for the modeling.

Mitigation systems to be considered include chlorine leak detection equipment and vacuum piping.  The vacuum piping system is expected to significantly reduce the amount of chlorine released in case of a pigtial or piping failure. 

Release Prevention Program

The HCWD general release prevention program is based on several key elements:

     High level of training of operations and maintenance staff.
     Preventative Maintenance Program
     State of the art process and safety equipment
     Accurate, effective operating procedures
     Hazard review of equipment and procedures
     An in-house inspection program

Chemical specific prevention steps include availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of the chlorine supply, awareness of hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine and the presence of sophisticated chlorine detection systems.
